lesson_title: Understanding Word Parts: Prefixes, Suffixes, and Roots
objectives: Identify common prefixes, suffixes, and root words.
Understand how prefixes and suffixes change the meaning and function of a word.
Use knowledge of word parts to determine the meaning of unfamiliar words.
Expand vocabulary by recognizing word families.

topics.title: Prefixes: Modifying Meaning at the Beginning

sections.text: A prefix is a group of letters added to the beginning of a word to change its meaning. For example, adding the prefix 'un-' to the word 'happy' creates 'unhappy,' which means not happy. Understanding prefixes can help you quickly figure out the meaning of new words.

examples.label: happy -> unhappy
examples.value: He was happy with his results, but his friend was unhappy.

examples.label: do -> redo
examples.value: Your homework is messy; please redo it.

examples.label: possible -> impossible
examples.value: With hard work, what seems impossible can become possible.

examples.label: view -> preview
examples.value: We saw a preview of the new movie.

examples.label: like -> dislike
examples.value: I like mangoes, but I dislike jackfruit.

examples.label: write -> rewrite
examples.value: The teacher asked him to rewrite the essay.

usage_examples: Prefixes attach to the start of a root word.
They change the word's meaning.
'Re-' often means 'again'.
'Un-' often means 'not'.
Knowing prefixes expands your vocabulary.

subtopics.title: Common Prefixes: un-, dis-, re-, pre-, mis-, im-

sections.text: Many prefixes give a negative meaning or show repetition. 'un-', 'dis-', and 'im-' often mean 'not' or 'the opposite of'. 're-' means 'again'. 'pre-' means 'before'. 'mis-' means 'wrongly' or 'badly'.

examples.label: un- (not)
examples.value: The old well is unsafe for drinking.

examples.label: un- (not)
examples.value: He was unable to lift the heavy sack.

examples.label: un- (not)
examples.value: It is unkind to laugh at others' mistakes.

examples.label: dis- (opposite of)
examples.value: I disagree with his plan to sell the land.

examples.label: dis- (opposite of)
examples.value: The magician made the rabbit disappear.

examples.label: dis- (opposite of)
examples.value: It is dishonest to steal.

examples.label: re- (again)
examples.value: We need to rebuild the broken fence.

examples.label: re- (again)
examples.value: Please review your answers before submitting.

examples.label: re- (again)
examples.value: She had to retake the test.

examples.label: pre- (before)
examples.value: We attended a pre-wedding ceremony.

examples.label: pre- (before)
examples.value: It is important to pre-heat the oven before baking.

examples.label: mis- (wrongly)
examples.value: I misunderstood his instructions.

examples.label: mis- (wrongly)
examples.value: Be careful not to misplace your keys.

examples.label: mis- (wrongly)
examples.value: His bad behaviour is a result of his misdeeds.

examples.label: im- (not)
examples.value: The patient was very ill, but not in immediate danger.

examples.label: im- (not)
examples.value: It is impolite to interrupt when someone is speaking.

usage_examples: The story was unbelievable.
She dislikes spicy food.
He had to rewrite the entire letter.
The prehistoric fossils were found nearby.
His spelling mistakes are due to misreading the words.

topics.title: Suffixes: Changing Meaning at the End

sections.text: A suffix is a group of letters added to the end of a word. Suffixes can change a word's meaning, but more often, they change its function or part of speech. For example, adding '-ness' to the adjective 'kind' creates the noun 'kindness'.

examples.label: kind (adj) -> kindness (noun)
examples.value: He showed great kindness to the new family.

examples.label: work (verb) -> worker (noun)
examples.value: My father is a farmer, a hard worker.

examples.label: hope (noun) -> hopeful (adj)
examples.value: We are hopeful for a good harvest this year.

examples.label: danger (noun) -> dangerous (adj)
examples.value: Walking alone at night can be dangerous.

examples.label: act (verb) -> action (noun)
examples.value: Every action has a consequence.

examples.label: quick (adj) -> quickly (adverb)
examples.value: The deer ran quickly into the forest.

usage_examples: Suffixes come at the end of a word.
They can change a word from an adjective to a noun.
'-ful' means 'full of'.
'-less' means 'without'.
Learning suffixes helps you build more words.

sections.text: Suffixes can turn words into adjectives, nouns, or adverbs. '-able' means 'can be done'. '-ful' means 'full of'. '-less' means 'without'. '-ness' creates a noun showing a state or quality. '-ly' often turns an adjective into an adverb. '-ion' turns a verb into a noun showing an action or process.

examples.label: -able (can be done)
examples.value: The water from this tap is drinkable.

examples.label: -able (can be done)
examples.value: This old cloth is still usable.

examples.label: -ful (full of)
examples.value: The farmer was thankful for the rain.

examples.label: -ful (full of)
examples.value: The peacock has beautiful, colorful feathers.

examples.label: -less (without)
examples.value: A farmer's work is endless.

examples.label: -less (without)
examples.value: He made a careless mistake.

examples.label: -ness (state of being)
examples.value: Happiness is seeing healthy crops.

examples.label: -ness (state of being)
examples.value: Illness can make a person weak.

examples.label: -ly (in a certain way)
examples.value: He carefully planted the seeds.

examples.label: -ly (in a certain way)
examples.value: She spoke softly so as not to wake the baby.

examples.label: -ion (act of)
examples.value: His decision to move to the city was difficult.

examples.label: -ion (act of)
examples.value: The celebration after the harvest was joyous.

usage_examples: This book is very enjoyable.
The colorful flowers look beautiful.
He felt hopeless after the flood.
Her kindness is well-known in the village.
She quietly entered the room.
His collection of old coins is impressive.

sections.text: A root word is the most basic part of a word that holds its core meaning. Many English words have roots from older languages like Latin and Greek. By recognizing the root, you can guess the meaning of a whole family of words. For example, the root 'port' means 'to carry'.

examples.label: Root: 'port' (to carry)
examples.value: We transport goods from the village to the city.

examples.label: Root: 'port' (to carry)
examples.value: He works as a reporter, carrying news to the people.

examples.label: Root: 'spect' (to see)
examples.value: We must respect our elders.

examples.label: Root: 'spect' (to see)
examples.value: The village head will inspect the new well tomorrow.

examples.label: Root: 'form' (to shape)
examples.value: Please fill out this information form.

examples.label: Root: 'form' (to shape)
examples.value: The caterpillar will transform into a butterfly.

usage_examples: The root is the heart of a word.
Prefixes and suffixes can be added to roots.
Knowing one root can unlock many words.
'Tele' means 'far', and 'vision' means 'to see'.
'Bio' means 'life', and 'logy' means 'study of'.

subtopics.title: Common Roots: port, spect, struct, dict, vis, form

sections.text: Learning common roots is a powerful vocabulary-building tool. 'port' means to carry. 'spect' means to look or see. 'struct' means to build. 'dict' means to say or speak. 'vis' means to see. 'form' means to shape.

examples.label: port (to carry)
examples.value: India exports tea to many countries. (carries out)

examples.label: port (to carry)
examples.value: This small radio is portable. (can be carried)

examples.label: port (to carry)
examples.value: It is important to support your family.

examples.label: spect (to look)
examples.value: The villagers became spectators at the festival. (people who look)

examples.label: spect (to look)
examples.value: The old farmer wears spectacles to read. (glasses to see)

examples.label: spect (to look)
examples.value: From the hilltop, the perspective of the valley was amazing.

examples.label: struct (to build)
examples.value: The construction of the new school will begin soon. (the act of building)

examples.label: struct (to build)
examples.value: Please follow the instructions carefully. (information that builds knowledge)

examples.label: struct (to build)
examples.value: You need to structure your essay properly.

examples.label: dict (to say)
examples.value: The leader's words contradicted his actions. (spoke against)

examples.label: dict (to say)
examples.value: The astrologer tried to predict the future. (say before)

examples.label: vis (to see)
examples.value: The mountain was visible from our village.

examples.label: vis (to see)
examples.value: He had a vision of a prosperous future for his village.

examples.label: form (to shape)
examples.value: The soldiers stood in formation.

examples.label: form (to shape)
examples.value: The government promised to reform the land laws.

usage_examples: He gave an important speech.
We must not disrespect our traditions.
The destruction from the storm was immense.
The verdict was announced in court.
It's important to revise before an exam.
A good uniform makes students look smart.
